# Codebrainery.io

## Project Brief

Objective

How to Make a Website with NameCheap

### Codebrainery.io

Codebrainery.io is a learn-to-code website. Let’s build their homepage using a combination of Bootstrap and custom CSS, provided by the file **style.css**.

If you get stuck during this project, check out the **project walkthrough video** which can be found in the help menu.


-   an h1 element with the class “col-sm-8”. Have it display the text “Codebrainery.io”.

You can think of these elements as the \\"brains\\" of a webpage because they communicate vital information to the web browser, but are not visible to a webpage visitor. \\n\\n1. \`\\u003c!DOCTYPE html\\u003e\`: Tells the web browser to expect an HTML document.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n2. \`\\u003chtml\\u003e...\\u003c/html\\u003e\`: The root of the HTML document and parent of all other HTML elements on the webpage.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n3. \`\\u003chead\\u003e...\\u003c/head\\u003e\`: Enclose other metadata about the site, such as its title.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n \\n4. \`\\u003ctitle\\u003e...\\u003c/title\\u003e\`: Contains the site's title, which is one way users can find your site through a search engine, like Google.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e \\n\\n5. \`\\u003cmeta charset=\\"utf-8\\"/\\u003e\`: Tells the web browser which character set to use. In this case, the character set is \\"utf-8\\". You've learned enough HTML to create a great website! \\n\\nBefore we move on to styling with CSS, let's review what we learned in this lesson. \\n\\n#### Languages\\n\* \_\_html\_\_: stands for \_hypertext markup language\_, and is used to give a webpage structure.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\* \_\_css\_\_: stands for \_cascading style sheets\_, and is used to style HTML elements.\\n\\n#### HTML Elements \\n\* \_h1 - h6\_: indicate text headings on a webpage. h1 is the largest heading; h6 is the smallest. \\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003ch1\\u003eHeading\\u003c/h1\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_p\_: used for non-heading text, such as the bodies of articles or company descriptions.\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003cp\\u003eDescription of company here.\\u003c/p\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_a\_: short for anchor and used to add links to other webpages. Anchor elements typically have an href attribute: \\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003ca href=\\"http://codecademy.com\\"\\u003eClick here\\u003c/a\\u003e to learn how to make a website!\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_img\_: used to add an image to a webpage. Image elements are \_self-closing\_ and do not require a closing tag: \\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003cimg src=\\"https://images.com/favorite.png\\"\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_video\_: used to add videos to a webpage, and uses multiple attributes and a nested source element: \\n\\n \`\`\`html\\n \\u003cvideo width=\\"320\\" height=\\"240\\" controls\\u003e\\n \\u003csource src=\\"https://movies.io/great-clip.mp4\\" type=\\"video/mp4\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003c/video\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_unordered list\_: used to create lists on a webpage and requires li elements inside a ul: \\n\\n \`\`\`html\\n \\u003cul\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003elist item\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003eanother item\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003eyet another\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003c/ul\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_div\_: used to organize HTML elements into different groups, which can be given a class attribute: \\n \`\`\`html \\n \\u003cdiv class=\\"main\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003ch2\\u003eSubheading!\\u003c/h2\\u003e\\n \\u003c/div\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_metadata tags\_: provide metadata about a webpage. \\n\\n#### Web Concepts \\n\* \_\_parent/child elements\_\_: used to describe HTML elements that enclose or are enclosed by other elements. Like the HTML image element, link is self-closing. It does not need a closing tag. \\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n3. In the example above, \_\_main.css\_\_ is an external style sheet. For many situations, these named colors will suffice. However, web developers who want to get even more exact with their color choices can use \_hexadecimal\_ and \_RGB\_ color values.\\n \\n1. \_Hexadecimal color (#RRGGBB)\_: Hexadecimal values that represent mixtures of red, green and blue. For example, red can be expressed with the hexadecimal value of \`#FF0000\`: the value \`ff\` represents red, \`00\` represents green, and \`00\` represents blue.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n2. \_RGB (Red, Green, Blue) colors\_: Color created by three numbers representing red, green, and blue. CSS styles applied to the \`header\` \_class selector\_ will automatically apply to the \`h2\` and the \`p\`.\\n\\n\\u003ca href=\\"https://www.codecademy.com/en/courses/make-a-website/lessons/site-structure/exercises/parent-child\\" target=\_blank\\u003eHere's a refresher\\u003c/a\\u003e on parent and child elements. \\n\\nIn CSS, class selectors can be identified by a dot \`.\` followed by the class name, as seen below: \\n\\n\`\`\`css\\n.header {\\n color: #ffffff; \\n}\\n\`\`\`\\nAs a result of this code, child elements of divs with the \`header\` class will have a font color of \`#ffffff\` (white). \\n\\nBelow, we will use a CSS class selector to style more than one HTML element at once. size of text has an impact on how users experience a website. The \*font-size\* property sets the size of an HTML element's text. \\n\\n\`\`\`css\\nh1 {\\n font-size: 60px; \\n}\\n\`\`\`\\n\\nIn the CSS above, \`font-size\` is set to \`60px\`. In CSS, size can be assigned in \_pixels\_ (px), \_rems\_, or \_ems\_. \\n\\n1. \_pixel (px)\_: Standard unit of measurement for sizing fonts and other HTML elements.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n2. \_rem\_: Represents the default font size for the web browser. Rems can be used to ensure that HTML elements scale in proportion to each other on various web browsers and screen sizes. On most web browsers, \`1rem\` is equivalent to \`16px\`, \`2rem\` is equivalent to \`32px\` (a doubling), 3rem is equivalent to \`48px\` (a tripling) and so on.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n3. \_em\_: A relative value that changes in proportion to the \`font-size\` of the element on which \`em\` is used. Because \`font-size\` is an inherited property, this usually means the \`em\` value will change in proportion to the \`font-size\` of the parent element unless a \`font-size\` is explicitly set on the element on which \`em\` is used. For example, if a parent element has \`font-size: 20px;\`, child elements with \`font-size: 1em;\` would be equivalent to \`20px\`. Child elements with \`font-size: 0.5em;\` would be equivalent to \`10px\` (a halving) and so on.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\nWe will primarily explore px and rem values since these are the most commonly used today. What if a webpage design calls for an individual page element to be styled uniquely, but all other elements of that kind to be styled a different way? \\n\\nFor example, to style one anchor element differently than all the others on a webpage, you could use the HTML \_id attribute\_: \\n\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003ca id=\\"learn-code\\" href=\\"https://www.codecademy.com\\"\\u003eClick here to learn to code!\\u003c/a\\u003e \\n\`\`\` \\n\\nThen in the CSS file, you would create a rule for the id selector, using a \`#\` symbol: \\n\\n\`\`\`css\\n#learn-code {\\n color: #2e69a3; \\n}\\n\`\`\` \\n\\nAbout using id:\\n\\n1. An id attribute can only be used once because the id is unique to the element it is assigned to.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n2. Ids have greater specificity than classes. If an HTML element is using both id and class attributes, the CSS rule for the id will take precedence over that of the class. \\n\\nBelow we will use an id selector to style a single HTML element differently than others of that kind on the webpage. Consider creating your own personal portfolio site!\\n\\nThriving as a programmer in today’s job market requires a forward-thinking skill-set. One way to demonstrate this to prospective employers is through displaying your personal portfolio online. Paper resumés alone rarely suffice in opening the door to an interview, especially when job sites have streamlined the process of submitting PDFs of resumés online. Building your own personal portfolio allows employers to see your coding competence, creativity, and personality.\\n\\nNot only that but as you further your skills in web design and create more projects, you can iterate on your personal portfolio site. As your own skills increase, so will the quality and breadth of content on display. When cultivated correctly, a personal portfolio site can be a reflection of your growth as a developer.\\n\\n## Getting Started\\n\\nThis upcoming learning module is intended not only to guide you in building your personal portfolio but also to teach you how to deploy and host that site on the internet so anyone can find it. This will be done in three stages:\\n \\n### Building the Site\\nFirst, you will complete a project that will have you build your first portfolio site. Remember, this site is about you, so feel free to deviate from the project when you feel inspired, and put as much of your own personality into the work as you can.\\n\\n### Registering a Domain Name\\nIn partnership with Namecheap, a great domain name registrar, we are excited to offer our learners who complete this project a free domain name registration for a full year. We'll walk you through how to pick a good domain name, and how to sign up with Namecheap.\\n\\n### Hosting your Website\\nFinally, once you have your site and domain name, we'll take you through the process of hosting that site with Namecheap's Stellar hosting service. \\n\\nLet's build a website!","progress":{"\_\_typename":"ContentItemProgressSummary","content\_item\_id":"5eaee9f14a6a9bcc0b188f1dc5d81a19","started":false,"started\_at":null,"completed":false,"completed\_at":null,"user\_completed":false,"user\_completed\_at":null,"user\_id":"630d6dcc8af48773d981c008","last\_updated":null,"record":null}},"923d2bbba70a4bddab9cfaa3fd0e8397":{"\_\_typename":"Lesson","id":"923d2bbba70a4bddab9cfaa3fd0e8397","description":"In created your own beautiful personal portfolio and now you want to share it with the world. But how do you do that?\\n\\n#### Web Hosting\\n\\nOnce you create the files that make up your website, you need a \*web hosting server\* to store those files in a location that other people can access. Typically these servers are owned by web hosting companies, such as \\u003ca href=\\"https://namecheap.pxf.io/k20jz\\" rel=\\"\\"\\u003e Namecheap \\u003c/a\\u003e. These companies will host your website and make it available to everyone on the internet for a monthly fee.\\n\\n#### Domain Names\\n\\nIn addition to the web hosting server, you also need a \*domain name\*. A domain name is a human-friendly address that allows anyone to connect to your specific IP address, and thus, access your website. An IP address by itself is a series of numbers and decimals which can be hard to remember, especially given the number of websites an average person visits in a day! Codecademy's own IP address is 104.20.25.250 but since it owns the domain name \`codecademy.com\`, a user only needs to remember to type the domain into the browser to access the site.\\n\\nThese relationships between IP addresses and domain names are all stored on \_domain name servers\_, which translate what you type into your browser to an actual address.\\n\\n#### How Vistors Connect to your Site\\n\\nIf you put this all together, you have a picture of how a website works. \\n+ A visitor will type your domain name into their browser. \\n+ The domain name server translates this domain name into the IP address of the web hosting server, where your website is stored. \\n+ The web hosting server then sends the website back to the visitor's computer, where it is loaded in their browser. \\n\\nVoilà, Jessica from Melbourne, Australia is now looking at your personal portfolio on her computer!","instructions":null},{"\_\_typename":"LayoutImage","id":"5d65463592bc1c7f89fe378c","type":"Image","image\_url":"https://content.codecademy.com/courses/updated\_images/WebHostingDiagram\_Updated\_1.svg","alt\_text":"Diagram domain name, like \`codecademy.com\` consists of two parts:\\n+ The second level domain which is to the left of the period (\`codecademy\`)\\n+ The top-level domain (TLD) which is to the right of the period (\`.com\`). \\n\\nWith Namecheap, you get to choose both!\\n\\nA domain name should highlight what your website is about. If you're selling robotic squirrels, for example, \`robosquirrels.com\` might be a fitting name for your site. But you'll have to contend with whether or not your dream domain name has already been taken—all Domain Name Registrars have a search bar that determines a domain name’s availability. Namecheap provides their own \\u003ca href=\\"https://www.namecheap.com/domains/domain-name-search/?clickID=zkoy0qQIZxyJRi-wUx0Mo382UklX-yzbSSNGyM0\\u0026irgwc=1\\u0026utm\_source=IR\\u0026utm\_medium=Affiliate\\u0026utm\_campaign=1356525\\u0026affnetwork=ir\\u0026ref=ir\\" rel=\\"\\"\\u003e search \\u003c/a\\u003e.\\n\\nSince \`.com\` has been around for so long, many \`.com\` domain names are unavailable or unaffordable. For your own site, try using a newer second-level domain, such as \`.tech\`, \`.world\`, or \`.website\`. \\n\\n#### What Makes a Good Domain Name? ####\\n\\nA domain name should be short, memorable, and easy to spell. When you decide on your name, share it with some friends or colleagues. Will they be able to spell it correctly? If possible, stay away from using numbers, hyphens, or abbreviations in place of actual words within domain names as a user could easily misinterpret and misspell your domain (eg. \`doughnuts4u\` or \`ready2d8\`). \\n\\nAlso, consider if your spelling could be misconstrued or have unintended associations. For example, an aspiring web developer might create a website dedicated to words that begin with her favorite letter, “s”, and think \`sWords.com\` would be a fantastic domain name choice. Domain names, though, are not case-sensitive. As an unintended consequence, she may find out that her site is visited mostly by sword-collectors and history enthusiasts. \\n\\nSince your goal is to deploy your personal portfolio, try to see if your own name is available as a \`yourfullname.me\` or \`yourfullname.tech\` format.\\n\\n#### What Top Level Domain Should I Choose? ####\\n\\nAll top-level domains are equal in the eyes of a Google search so whether you go with \`.world\`, \`.me\`, \`.tech\`, or \`.rocks\`, it will have no overall impact on your site's search engine performance.\\n\\nThe choice of TLD’s has recently expanded greatly with new options like \`.store\`, \`.space\`, and even \`.ninja\`! Namecheap has a \[comprehensive list of TLD’s\](https://namecheap.pxf.io/c/1356525/386170/5618?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.namecheap.com%2Fdomains%2Fnew-tlds%2Fexplore%2F). \\n\\nOn the next page, you'll get to see all of the top-level domains that they are offering Codecademy learners for free!","instructions":null},{"\_\_typename":"LayoutImage","id":"5d277fa231c949698acf41f6","type":"Image","image\_url":"https://content.codecademy.com/courses/domain-name/domain.svg","alt\_text":"Image of a domain name and it's components."}\]},{"\_\_typename":"Exercise","id":"b9b047709aebddaebf89f61e75926746","sourceId":null,"title":"Registering a Domain Name with Namecheap","slug":"registering-your-domain","published":true,"setup\_command":null,"created\_at":"2019-04-25T13:46:29Z","checkpoints":\[\],"ein\_config":{"container\_type":"static-web","server":"http"},"last\_modified\_at":"2020-02-25T18:03:37Z","workspace":{"\_\_typename":"Workspace","id":"5e556189a25dee00118861d3","slug":"setting-up-your-domain-purchasing-your-domain","type":"static-web"},"components":\[{"\_\_typename":"Narrative","id":"5cc1ba693709021ca9248516","type":"Narrative","content":"A domain can be selected and purchased for one-year’s usage \\u0026mdash; which is standard practice among Domain Name Registrars. The webpage is starting to come together. \\n\\nWhat if you wanted to link users to a different webpage? The HTML \_anchor\_ element makes it possible to do this with a single click. \\n\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003ca href=\\"http://google.com\\"\\u003eClick here for Google!\\u003c/a\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\n\\nAnchor elements use an \_attribute\_ to link users to websites. You can think of these elements as the \\"brains\\" of a webpage because they communicate vital information to the web browser, but are not visible to a webpage visitor. \\n\\n1. \`\\u003c!DOCTYPE html\\u003e\`: Tells the web browser to expect an HTML document.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n2. \`\\u003chtml\\u003e...\\u003c/html\\u003e\`: The root of the HTML document and parent of all other HTML elements on the webpage.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n3. \`\\u003chead\\u003e...\\u003c/head\\u003e\`: Enclose other metadata about the site, such as its title.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n \\n4. \`\\u003ctitle\\u003e...\\u003c/title\\u003e\`: Contains the site's title, which is one way users can find your site through a search engine, like Google.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e \\n\\n5. \`\\u003cmeta charset=\\"utf-8\\"/\\u003e\`: Tells the web browser which character set to use. In this case, the character set is \\"utf-8\\". You've learned enough HTML to create a great website! \\n\\nBefore we move on to styling with CSS, let's review what we learned in this lesson. \\n\\n#### Languages\\n\* \_\_html\_\_: stands for \_hypertext markup language\_, and is used to give a webpage structure.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\* \_\_css\_\_: stands for \_cascading style sheets\_, and is used to style HTML elements.\\n\\n#### HTML Elements \\n\* \_h1 - h6\_: indicate text headings on a webpage. h1 is the largest heading; h6 is the smallest. \\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003ch1\\u003eHeading\\u003c/h1\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_p\_: used for non-heading text, such as the bodies of articles or company descriptions.\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003cp\\u003eDescription of company here.\\u003c/p\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_a\_: short for anchor and used to add links to other webpages. Anchor elements typically have an href attribute: \\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003ca href=\\"http://codecademy.com\\"\\u003eClick here\\u003c/a\\u003e to learn how to make a website!\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_img\_: used to add an image to a webpage. Image elements are \_self-closing\_ and do not require a closing tag: \\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003cimg src=\\"https://images.com/favorite.png\\"\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_video\_: used to add videos to a webpage, and uses multiple attributes and a nested source element: \\n\\n \`\`\`html\\n \\u003cvideo width=\\"320\\" height=\\"240\\" controls\\u003e\\n \\u003csource src=\\"https://movies.io/great-clip.mp4\\" type=\\"video/mp4\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003c/video\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_unordered list\_: used to create lists on a webpage and requires li elements inside a ul: \\n\\n \`\`\`html\\n \\u003cul\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003elist item\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003eanother item\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003eyet another\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003c/ul\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_div\_: used to organize HTML elements into different groups, which can be given a class attribute: \\n \`\`\`html \\n \\u003cdiv class=\\"main\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003ch2\\u003eSubheading!\\u003c/h2\\u003e\\n \\u003c/div\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_metadata tags\_: provide metadata about a webpage. \\n\\n#### Web Concepts \\n\* \_\_parent/child elements\_\_: used to describe HTML elements that enclose or are enclosed by other elements. For example, below the ul is the parent and the li items are children: \\n\\n \`\`\`html\\n \\u003cul\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003e...\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003e...\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003e...\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003c/ul\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\nClick Up Next to start learning about CSS!\\n\\n","instructions":null}\]}\],"progress":{"\_\_typename":"LessonProgressSummary","content\_item\_id":"ee774be96f1b8dbe870bd67c0745d815","started":true,"started\_at":"2023-11-08T15:18:34+00:00","completed":true,"completed\_at":"2023-11-08T15:33:43+00:00","user\_completed":false,"user\_completed\_at":null,"user\_id":"630d6dcc8af48773d981c008","last\_updated":"2023-11-08T15:33:43+00:00","record":{"\_\_typename":"Progress","state":{"\_\_typename":"ProgressState","attempts":null,"bookmark":\[13,0\],"checklist":null,"kanban":null}},"type":"lesson","progress\_pct":100,"exercises\_completed":13,"exercises\_total":13,"current\_exercise\_checkpoints\_completed":0}},{"\_\_typename":"Project","id":"f4e3863c39ba4e574caac43d1a0a3741","description":"Build two webpages for an up-and-coming band using fundamental HTML elements. Here's an example of the link element: \\n\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003clink rel=\\"stylesheet\\" type=\\"text/css\\" href=\\"main.css\\"/\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\nAbout \_link\_: \\n\\n1. The link element uses three attributes:\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n -\`rel\`: Specifies the \_relationship\_ between the current file and the file being linked to: in this case, the \`rel\` attribute is \\"stylesheet\\".\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n -\`type\`: Specifies the type of file linked to.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n -\`href\`: Provides the URL of the file being linked to.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n2. Like the HTML image element, link is self-closing. It does not need a closing tag. \\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n3. In the example above, \_\_main.css\_\_ is an external style sheet. Using external stylesheets is one of the most popular ways to write CSS. CSS styles applied to the \`header\` \_class selector\_ will automatically apply to the \`h2\` and the \`p\`.\\n\\n\\u003ca href=\\"https://www.codecademy.com/en/courses/make-a-website/lessons/site-structure/exercises/parent-child\\" target=\_blank\\u003eHere's a refresher\\u003c/a\\u003e on parent and child elements. \\n\\nIn CSS, class selectors can be identified by a dot \`.\` followed by the class name, as seen below: \\n\\n\`\`\`css\\n.header {\\n color: #ffffff; \\n}\\n\`\`\`\\nAs a result of this code, child elements of divs with the \`header\` class will have a font color of \`#ffffff\` (white). \\n\\nBelow, we will use a CSS class selector to style more than one HTML element at once. size of text has an impact on how users experience a website. The \*font-size\* property sets the size of an HTML element's text. \\n\\n\`\`\`css\\nh1 {\\n font-size: 60px; \\n}\\n\`\`\`\\n\\nIn the CSS above, \`font-size\` is set to \`60px\`. In CSS, size can be assigned in \_pixels\_ (px), \_rems\_, or \_ems\_. \\n\\n1. \_pixel (px)\_: Standard unit of measurement for sizing fonts and other HTML elements.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n2. \_rem\_: Represents the default font size for the web browser. Rems can be used to ensure that HTML elements scale in proportion to each other on various web browsers and screen sizes. On most web browsers, \`1rem\` is equivalent to \`16px\`, \`2rem\` is equivalent to \`32px\` (a doubling), 3rem is equivalent to \`48px\` (a tripling) and so on.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n3. \_em\_: A relative value that changes in proportion to the \`font-size\` of the element on which \`em\` is used. Because \`font-size\` is an inherited property, this usually means the \`em\` value will change in proportion to the \`font-size\` of the parent element unless a \`font-size\` is explicitly set on the element on which \`em\` is used. For example, if a parent element has \`font-size: 20px;\`, child elements with \`font-size: 1em;\` would be equivalent to \`20px\`. Child elements with \`font-size: 0.5em;\` would be equivalent to \`10px\` (a halving) and so on.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\nWe will primarily explore px and rem values since these are the most commonly used today. created your own beautiful personal portfolio and now you want to share it with the world. But how do you do that?\\n\\n#### Web Hosting\\n\\nOnce you create the files that make up your website, you need a \*web hosting server\* to store those files in a location that other people can access. Typically these servers are owned by web hosting companies, such as \\u003ca href=\\"https://namecheap.pxf.io/k20jz\\" rel=\\"\\"\\u003e Namecheap \\u003c/a\\u003e. These companies will host your website and make it available to everyone on the internet for a monthly fee.\\n\\n#### Domain Names\\n\\nIn addition to the web hosting server, you also need a \*domain name\*. A domain name is a human-friendly address that allows anyone to connect to your specific IP address, and thus, access your website. An IP address by itself is a series of numbers and decimals which can be hard to remember, especially given the number of websites an average person visits in a day! Codecademy's own IP address is 104.20.25.250 but since it owns the domain name \`codecademy.com\`, a user only needs to remember to type the domain into the browser to access the site.\\n\\nThese relationships between IP addresses and domain names are all stored on \_domain name servers\_, which translate what you type into your browser to an actual address.\\n\\n#### How Vistors Connect to your Site\\n\\nIf you put this all together, you have a picture of how a website works. \\n+ A visitor will type your domain name into their browser. \\n+ The domain name server translates this domain name into the IP address of the web hosting server, where your website is stored. \\n+ The web hosting server then sends the website back to the visitor's computer, where it is loaded in their browser. \\n\\nVoilà, Jessica from Melbourne, Australia is now looking at your personal portfolio on her computer!","instructions":null},{"\_\_typename":"LayoutImage","id":"5d65463592bc1c7f89fe378c","type":"Image","image\_url":"https://content.codecademy.com/courses/updated\_images/WebHostingDiagram\_Updated\_1.svg","alt\_text":"Diagram domain name, like \`codecademy.com\` consists of two parts:\\n+ The second level domain which is to the left of the period (\`codecademy\`)\\n+ The top-level domain (TLD) which is to the right of the period (\`.com\`). \\n\\nWith Namecheap, you get to choose both!\\n\\nA domain name should highlight what your website is about. If you're selling robotic squirrels, for example, \`robosquirrels.com\` might be a fitting name for your site. But you'll have to contend with whether or not your dream domain name has already been taken—all Domain Name Registrars have a search bar that determines a domain name’s availability. Namecheap provides their own \\u003ca href=\\"https://www.namecheap.com/domains/domain-name-search/?clickID=zkoy0qQIZxyJRi-wUx0Mo382UklX-yzbSSNGyM0\\u0026irgwc=1\\u0026utm\_source=IR\\u0026utm\_medium=Affiliate\\u0026utm\_campaign=1356525\\u0026affnetwork=ir\\u0026ref=ir\\" rel=\\"\\"\\u003e search \\u003c/a\\u003e.\\n\\nSince \`.com\` has been around for so long, many \`.com\` domain names are unavailable or unaffordable. For your own site, try using a newer second-level domain, such as \`.tech\`, \`.world\`, or \`.website\`. \\n\\n#### What Makes a Good Domain Name? ####\\n\\nA domain name should be short, memorable, and easy to spell. When you decide on your name, share it with some friends or colleagues. Will they be able to spell it correctly? If possible, stay away from using numbers, hyphens, or abbreviations in place of actual words within domain names as a user could easily misinterpret and misspell your domain (eg. \`doughnuts4u\` or \`ready2d8\`). \\n\\nAlso, consider if your spelling could be misconstrued or have unintended associations. For example, an aspiring web developer might create a website dedicated to words that begin with her favorite letter, “s”, and think \`sWords.com\` would be a fantastic domain name choice. Domain names, though, are not case-sensitive. As an unintended consequence, she may find out that her site is visited mostly by sword-collectors and history enthusiasts. \\n\\nSince your goal is to deploy your personal portfolio, try to see if your own name is available as a \`yourfullname.me\` or \`yourfullname.tech\` format.\\n\\n#### What Top Level Domain Should I Choose? ####\\n\\nAll top-level domains are equal in the eyes of a Google search so whether you go with \`.world\`, \`.me\`, \`.tech\`, or \`.rocks\`, it will have no overall impact on your site's search engine performance.\\n\\nThe choice of TLD’s has recently expanded greatly with new options like \`.store\`, \`.space\`, and even \`.ninja\`! Namecheap has a \[comprehensive list of TLD’s\](https://namecheap.pxf.io/c/1356525/386170/5618?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.namecheap.com%2Fdomains%2Fnew-tlds%2Fexplore%2F). \\n\\nOn the next page, you'll get to see all of the top-level domains that they are offering Codecademy learners for free!","instructions":null},{"\_\_typename":"LayoutImage","id":"5d277fa231c949698acf41f6","type":"Image","image\_url":"https://content.codecademy.com/courses/domain-name/domain.svg","alt\_text":"Image of a domain name and it's components."}\]},{"\_\_typename":"Exercise","id":"b9b047709aebddaebf89f61e75926746","sourceId":null,"title":"Registering a Domain Name with Namecheap","slug":"registering-your-domain","published":true,"setup\_command":null,"created\_at":"2019-04-25T13:46:29Z","checkpoints":\[\],"ein\_config":{"container\_type":"static-web","server":"http"},"last\_modified\_at":"2020-02-25T18:03:37Z","workspace":{"\_\_typename":"Workspace","id":"5e556189a25dee00118861d3","slug":"setting-up-your-domain-purchasing-your-domain","type":"static-web"},"components":\[{"\_\_typename":"Narrative","id":"5cc1ba693709021ca9248516","type":"Narrative","content":"A domain can be selected and purchased for one-year’s usage \\u0026mdash; which is standard practice among Domain Name Registrars. created your own beautiful personal portfolio and now you want to share it with the world. But how do you do that?\\n\\n#### Web Hosting\\n\\nOnce you create the files that make up your website, you need a \*web hosting server\* to store those files in a location that other people can access. Typically these servers are owned by web hosting companies, such as \\u003ca href=\\"https://namecheap.pxf.io/k20jz\\" rel=\\"\\"\\u003e Namecheap \\u003c/a\\u003e. These companies will host your website and make it available to everyone on the internet for a monthly fee.\\n\\n#### Domain Names\\n\\nIn addition to the web hosting server, you also need a \*domain name\*. A domain name is a human-friendly address that allows anyone to connect to your specific IP address, and thus, access your website. An IP address by itself is a series of numbers and decimals which can be hard to remember, especially given the number of websites an average person visits in a day! Codecademy's own IP address is 104.20.25.250 but since it owns the domain name \`codecademy.com\`, a user only needs to remember to type the domain into the browser to access the site.\\n\\nThese relationships between IP addresses and domain names are all stored on \_domain name servers\_, which translate what you type into your browser to an actual address.\\n\\n#### How Vistors Connect to your Site\\n\\nIf you put this all together, you have a picture of how a website works. \\n+ A visitor will type your domain name into their browser. \\n+ The domain name server translates this domain name into the IP address of the web hosting server, where your website is stored. \\n+ The web hosting server then sends the website back to the visitor's computer, where it is loaded in their browser. \\n\\nVoilà, Jessica from Melbourne, Australia is now looking at your personal portfolio on her domain name, like \`codecademy.com\` consists of two parts:\\n+ The second level domain which is to the left of the period (\`codecademy\`)\\n+ The top-level domain (TLD) which is to the right of the period (\`.com\`). \\n\\nWith Namecheap, you get to choose both!\\n\\nA domain name should highlight what your website is about. If you're selling robotic squirrels, for example, \`robosquirrels.com\` might be a fitting name for your site. But you'll have to contend with whether or not your dream domain name has already been taken—all Domain Name Registrars have a search bar that determines a domain name’s availability. Namecheap provides their own \\u003ca href=\\"https://www.namecheap.com/domains/domain-name-search/?clickID=zkoy0qQIZxyJRi-wUx0Mo382UklX-yzbSSNGyM0\\u0026irgwc=1\\u0026utm\_source=IR\\u0026utm\_medium=Affiliate\\u0026utm\_campaign=1356525\\u0026affnetwork=ir\\u0026ref=ir\\" rel=\\"\\"\\u003e search \\u003c/a\\u003e.\\n\\nSince \`.com\` has been around for so long, many \`.com\` domain names are unavailable or unaffordable. For your own site, try using a newer second-level domain, such as \`.tech\`, \`.world\`, or \`.website\`. \\n\\n#### What Makes a Good Domain Name? ####\\n\\nA domain name should be short, memorable, and easy to spell. When you decide on your name, share it with some friends or colleagues. Will they be able to spell it correctly? If possible, stay away from using numbers, hyphens, or abbreviations in place of actual words within domain names as a user could easily misinterpret and misspell your domain (eg. \`doughnuts4u\` or \`ready2d8\`). \\n\\nAlso, consider if your spelling could be misconstrued or have unintended associations. For example, an aspiring web developer might create a website dedicated to words that begin with her favorite letter, “s”, and think \`sWords.com\` would be a fantastic domain name choice. Domain names, though, are not case-sensitive. As an unintended consequence, she may find out that her site is visited mostly by sword-collectors and history enthusiasts. \\n\\nSince your goal is to deploy your personal portfolio, try to see if your own name is available as a \`yourfullname.me\` or \`yourfullname.tech\` format.\\n\\n#### What Top Level Domain Should I Choose? ####\\n\\nAll top-level domains are equal in the eyes of a Google search so whether you go with \`.world\`, \`.me\`, \`.tech\`, or \`.rocks\`, it will have no overall impact on your site's search engine performance.\\n\\nThe choice of TLD’s has recently expanded greatly with new options like \`.store\`, \`.space\`, and even \`.ninja\`! Namecheap has a \[comprehensive list of TLD’s\](https://namecheap.pxf.io/c/1356525/386170/5618?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.namecheap.com%2Fdomains%2Fnew-tlds%2Fexplore%2F). \\n\\nOn the next page, you'll get to see all of the top-level domains that they are offering Codecademy learners for free!","instructions":null},{"\_\_typename":"LayoutImage","id":"5d277fa231c949698acf41f6","type":"Image","image\_url":"https://content.codecademy.com/courses/domain-name/domain.svg","alt\_text":"Image of a domain name and it's components."}\]},"b9b047709aebddaebf89f61e75926746":{"\_\_typename":"Exercise","id":"b9b047709aebddaebf89f61e75926746","sourceId":null,"title":"Registering a Domain Name with Namecheap","slug":"registering-your-domain","published":true,"setup\_command":null,"created\_at":"2019-04-25T13:46:29Z","checkpoints":\[\],"ein\_config":{"container\_type":"static-web","server":"http"},"last\_modified\_at":"2020-02-25T18:03:37Z","workspace":{"\_\_typename":"Workspace","id":"5e556189a25dee00118861d3","slug":"setting-up-your-domain-purchasing-your-domain","type":"static-web"},"components":\[{"\_\_typename":"Narrative","id":"5cc1ba693709021ca9248516","type":"Narrative","content":"A domain can be selected and purchased for one-year’s usage \\u0026mdash; which is standard practice among Domain Name Registrars. HTML elements are arranged to span different numbers of columns in order to create custom page layouts. \\n\\n","instructions":"In the diagram, observe the following: \\n\\n1. Bootstrap's grid columns are represented by 12 vertical bars. The boxes represent HTML elements.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n2. Here's an example of the link element: \\n\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003clink rel=\\"stylesheet\\" type=\\"text/css\\" href=\\"main.css\\"/\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\nAbout \_link\_: \\n\\n1. The link element uses three attributes:\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n -\`rel\`: Specifies the \_relationship\_ between the current file and the file being linked to: in this case, the \`rel\` attribute is \\"stylesheet\\".\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n -\`type\`: Specifies the type of file linked to.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n -\`href\`: Provides the URL of the file being linked to.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n2. Like the HTML image element, link is self-closing. It does not need a closing tag. \\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n3. In the example above, \_\_main.css\_\_ is an external style sheet. Using external stylesheets is one of the most popular ways to write CSS. However, black is not your only option when it comes to font color. \\n\\nIn CSS, the \*color\* property sets the color of a CSS selector's font: \\n\\n\`\`\`css\\nh1 {\\n color: red;\\n}\\n\`\`\`\\n\\nCSS comes equipped with 140 \_named colors\_, such as \`red\`, used above. For many situations, these named colors will suffice. However, web developers who want to get even more exact with their color choices can use \_hexadecimal\_ and \_RGB\_ color values.\\n \\n1. \_Hexadecimal color (#RRGGBB)\_: Hexadecimal values that represent mixtures of red, green and blue. For example, red can be expressed with the hexadecimal value of \`#FF0000\`: the value \`ff\` represents red, \`00\` represents green, and \`00\` represents blue.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n2. \_RGB (Red, Green, Blue) colors\_: Color created by three numbers representing red, green, and blue. When mixed together, the three values create a specific color. CSS styles applied to the \`header\` \_class selector\_ will automatically apply to the \`h2\` and the \`p\`.\\n\\n\\u003ca href=\\"https://www.codecademy.com/en/courses/make-a-website/lessons/site-structure/exercises/parent-child\\" target=\_blank\\u003eHere's a refresher\\u003c/a\\u003e on parent and child elements. \\n\\nIn CSS, class selectors can be identified by a dot \`.\` followed by the class name, as seen below: \\n\\n\`\`\`css\\n.header {\\n color: #ffffff; \\n}\\n\`\`\`\\nAs a result of this code, child elements of divs with the \`header\` class will have a font color of \`#ffffff\` (white). \\n\\nBelow, we will use a CSS class selector to style more than one HTML element at once. The \*font-size\* property sets the size of an HTML element's text. \\n\\n\`\`\`css\\nh1 {\\n font-size: 60px; \\n}\\n\`\`\`\\n\\nIn the CSS above, \`font-size\` is set to \`60px\`. In CSS, size can be assigned in \_pixels\_ (px), \_rems\_, or \_ems\_. \\n\\n1. \_pixel (px)\_: Standard unit of measurement for sizing fonts and other HTML elements.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n2. \_rem\_: Represents the default font size for the web browser. Rems can be used to ensure that HTML elements scale in proportion to each other on various web browsers and screen sizes. On most web browsers, \`1rem\` is equivalent to \`16px\`, \`2rem\` is equivalent to \`32px\` (a doubling), 3rem is equivalent to \`48px\` (a tripling) and so on.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n3. \_em\_: A relative value that changes in proportion to the \`font-size\` of the element on which \`em\` is used. Because \`font-size\` is an inherited property, this usually means the \`em\` value will change in proportion to the \`font-size\` of the parent element unless a \`font-size\` is explicitly set on the element on which \`em\` is used. For example, if a parent element has \`font-size: 20px;\`, child elements with \`font-size: 1em;\` would be equivalent to \`20px\`. Child elements with \`font-size: 0.5em;\` would be equivalent to \`10px\` (a halving) and so on.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\nWe will primarily explore px and rem values since these are the most commonly used today. What if a webpage design calls for an individual page element to be styled uniquely, but all other elements of that kind to be styled a different way? \\n\\nFor example, to style one anchor element differently than all the others on a webpage, you could use the HTML \_id attribute\_: \\n\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003ca id=\\"learn-code\\" href=\\"https://www.codecademy.com\\"\\u003eClick here to learn to code!\\u003c/a\\u003e \\n\`\`\` \\n\\nThen in the CSS file, you would create a rule for the id selector, using a \`#\` symbol: \\n\\n\`\`\`css\\n#learn-code {\\n color: #2e69a3; \\n}\\n\`\`\` \\n\\nAbout using id:\\n\\n1. An id attribute can only be used once because the id is unique to the element it is assigned to.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n2. Ids have greater specificity than classes. If an HTML element is using both id and class attributes, the CSS rule for the id will take precedence over that of the class. \\n\\nBelow we will use an id selector to style a single HTML element differently than others of that kind on the webpage. In this case, the character set is \\"utf-8\\". You've learned enough HTML to create a great website! \\n\\nBefore we move on to styling with CSS, let's review what we learned in this lesson. \\n\\n#### Languages\\n\* \_\_html\_\_: stands for \_hypertext markup language\_, and is used to give a webpage structure.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\* \_\_css\_\_: stands for \_cascading style sheets\_, and is used to style HTML elements.\\n\\n#### HTML Elements \\n\* \_h1 - h6\_: indicate text headings on a webpage. h1 is the largest heading; h6 is the smallest. \\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003ch1\\u003eHeading\\u003c/h1\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_p\_: used for non-heading text, such as the bodies of articles or company descriptions.\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003cp\\u003eDescription of company here.\\u003c/p\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_a\_: short for anchor and used to add links to other webpages. Anchor elements typically have an href attribute: \\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003ca href=\\"http://codecademy.com\\"\\u003eClick here\\u003c/a\\u003e to learn how to make a website!\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_img\_: used to add an image to a webpage. Image elements are \_self-closing\_ and do not require a closing tag: \\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003cimg src=\\"https://images.com/favorite.png\\"\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_video\_: used to add videos to a webpage, and uses multiple attributes and a nested source element: \\n\\n \`\`\`html\\n \\u003cvideo width=\\"320\\" height=\\"240\\" controls\\u003e\\n \\u003csource src=\\"https://movies.io/great-clip.mp4\\" type=\\"video/mp4\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003c/video\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_unordered list\_: used to create lists on a webpage and requires li elements inside a ul: \\n\\n \`\`\`html\\n \\u003cul\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003elist item\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003eanother item\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003eyet another\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003c/ul\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_div\_: used to organize HTML elements into different groups, which can be given a class attribute: \\n \`\`\`html \\n \\u003cdiv class=\\"main\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003ch2\\u003eSubheading!\\u003c/h2\\u003e\\n \\u003c/div\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_metadata tags\_: provide metadata about a webpage. \\n\\n#### Web Concepts \\n\* \_\_parent/child elements\_\_: used to describe HTML elements that enclose or are enclosed by other elements. For example, below the ul is the parent and the li items are children: \\n\\n \`\`\`html\\n \\u003cul\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003e...\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003e...\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003e...\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003c/ul\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\nClick Up Next to start learning about You've learned enough HTML to create a great website! \\n\\nBefore we move on to styling with CSS, let's review what we learned in this lesson. \\n\\n#### Languages\\n\* \_\_html\_\_: stands for \_hypertext markup language\_, and is used to give a webpage structure.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\* \_\_css\_\_: stands for \_cascading style sheets\_, and is used to style HTML elements.\\n\\n#### HTML Elements \\n\* \_h1 - h6\_: indicate text headings on a webpage. h1 is the largest heading; h6 is the smallest. \\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003ch1\\u003eHeading\\u003c/h1\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_p\_: used for non-heading text, such as the bodies of articles or company descriptions.\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003cp\\u003eDescription of company here.\\u003c/p\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_a\_: short for anchor and used to add links to other webpages. Anchor elements typically have an href attribute: \\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003ca href=\\"http://codecademy.com\\"\\u003eClick here\\u003c/a\\u003e to learn how to make a website!\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_img\_: used to add an image to a webpage. Image elements are \_self-closing\_ and do not require a closing tag: \\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003cimg src=\\"https://images.com/favorite.png\\"\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_video\_: used to add videos to a webpage, and uses multiple attributes and a nested source element: \\n\\n \`\`\`html\\n \\u003cvideo width=\\"320\\" height=\\"240\\" controls\\u003e\\n \\u003csource src=\\"https://movies.io/great-clip.mp4\\" type=\\"video/mp4\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003c/video\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_unordered list\_: used to create lists on a webpage and requires li elements inside a ul: \\n\\n \`\`\`html\\n \\u003cul\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003elist item\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003eanother item\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003eyet another\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003c/ul\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_div\_: used to organize HTML elements into different groups, which can be given a class attribute: \\n \`\`\`html \\n \\u003cdiv class=\\"main\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003ch2\\u003eSubheading!\\u003c/h2\\u003e\\n \\u003c/div\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_metadata tags\_: provide metadata about a webpage. \\n\\n#### Web Concepts \\n\* \_\_parent/child elements\_\_: used to describe HTML elements that enclose or are enclosed by other elements. For example, below the ul is the parent and the li items are children: \\n\\n \`\`\`html\\n \\u003cul\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003e...\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003e...\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003e...\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003c/ul\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\nClick Up Next to start learning about CSS!\\n\\n","instructions":null}\]}\],"progress":{"\_\_typename":"LessonProgressSummary","content\_item\_id":"ee774be96f1b8dbe870bd67c0745d815","started":true,"started\_at":"2023-11-08T15:18:34+00:00","completed":true,"completed\_at":"2023-11-08T15:33:43+00:00","user\_completed":false,"user\_completed\_at":null,"user\_id":"630d6dcc8af48773d981c008","last\_updated":"2023-11-08T15:33:43+00:00","record":{"\_\_typename":"Progress","state":{"\_\_typename":"ProgressState","attempts":null,"bookmark":\[13,0\],"checklist":null,"kanban":null}},"type":"lesson","progress\_pct":100,"exercises\_completed":13,"exercises\_total":13,"current\_exercise\_checkpoints\_completed":0}},{"\_\_typename":"Project","id":"f4e3863c39ba4e574caac43d1a0a3741","description":"Build two webpages for an up-and-coming band using fundamental HTML elements. Here's an example of the link element: \\n\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003clink rel=\\"stylesheet\\" type=\\"text/css\\" href=\\"main.css\\"/\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\nAbout \_link\_: \\n\\n1. The link element uses three attributes:\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n -\`rel\`: Specifies the \_relationship\_ between the current file and the file being linked to: in this case, the \`rel\` attribute is \\"stylesheet\\".\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n -\`type\`: Specifies the type of file linked to.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n -\`href\`: Provides the URL of the file being linked to.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n2. Like the HTML image element, link is self-closing. It does not need a closing tag. \\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n3. In the example above, \_\_main.css\_\_ is an external style sheet. Using external stylesheets is one of the most popular ways to write CSS. For many situations, these named colors will suffice. However, web developers who want to get even more exact with their color choices can use \_hexadecimal\_ and \_RGB\_ color values.\\n \\n1. \_Hexadecimal color (#RRGGBB)\_: Hexadecimal values that represent mixtures of red, green and blue. For example, red can be expressed with the hexadecimal value of \`#FF0000\`: the value \`ff\` represents red, \`00\` represents green, and \`00\` represents blue.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n2. \_RGB (Red, Green, Blue) colors\_: Color created by three numbers representing red, green, and blue. CSS styles applied to the \`header\` \_class selector\_ will automatically apply to the \`h2\` and the \`p\`.\\n\\n\\u003ca href=\\"https://www.codecademy.com/en/courses/make-a-website/lessons/site-structure/exercises/parent-child\\" target=\_blank\\u003eHere's a refresher\\u003c/a\\u003e on parent and child elements. \\n\\nIn CSS, class selectors can be identified by a dot \`.\` followed by the class name, as seen below: \\n\\n\`\`\`css\\n.header {\\n color: #ffffff; \\n}\\n\`\`\`\\nAs a result of this code, child elements of divs with the \`header\` class will have a font color of \`#ffffff\` (white). \\n\\nBelow, we will use a CSS class selector to style more than one HTML element at once. size of text has an impact on how users experience a website. The \*font-size\* property sets the size of an HTML element's text. \\n\\n\`\`\`css\\nh1 {\\n font-size: 60px; \\n}\\n\`\`\`\\n\\nIn the CSS above, \`font-size\` is set to \`60px\`. In CSS, size can be assigned in \_pixels\_ (px), \_rems\_, or \_ems\_. \\n\\n1. \_pixel (px)\_: Standard unit of measurement for sizing fonts and other HTML elements.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n2. \_rem\_: Represents the default font size for the web browser. Rems can be used to ensure that HTML elements scale in proportion to each other on various web browsers and screen sizes. On most web browsers, \`1rem\` is equivalent to \`16px\`, \`2rem\` is equivalent to \`32px\` (a doubling), 3rem is equivalent to \`48px\` (a tripling) and so on.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n3. \_em\_: A relative value that changes in proportion to the \`font-size\` of the element on which \`em\` is used. Because \`font-size\` is an inherited property, this usually means the \`em\` value will change in proportion to the \`font-size\` of the parent element unless a \`font-size\` is explicitly set on the element on which \`em\` is used. For example, if a parent element has \`font-size: 20px;\`, child elements with \`font-size: 1em;\` would be equivalent to \`20px\`. Child elements with \`font-size: 0.5em;\` would be equivalent to \`10px\` (a halving) and so on.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\nWe will primarily explore px and rem values since these are the most commonly used today. What if a webpage design calls for an individual page element to be styled uniquely, but all other elements of that kind to be styled a different way? \\n\\nFor example, to style one anchor element differently than all the others on a webpage, you could use the HTML \_id attribute\_: \\n\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003ca id=\\"learn-code\\" href=\\"https://www.codecademy.com\\"\\u003eClick here to learn to code!\\u003c/a\\u003e \\n\`\`\` \\n\\nThen in the CSS file, you would create a rule for the id selector, using a \`#\` symbol: \\n\\n\`\`\`css\\n#learn-code {\\n color: #2e69a3; \\n}\\n\`\`\` \\n\\nAbout using id:\\n\\n1. An id attribute can only be used once because the id is unique to the element it is assigned to.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n2. Ids have greater specificity than classes. If an HTML element is using both id and class attributes, the CSS rule for the id will take precedence over that of the class. \\n\\nBelow we will use an id selector to style a single HTML element differently than others of that kind on the webpage. You've made it to the bottom of the webpage: the \_footer\_!\\n\\nFooters display copyright information, social media links, and sometimes, site navigation. \\n\\nBelow is one possible implementation for a footer section using Bootstrap: \\n\\nFirst, a footer element with Bootstrap's \`container\` class is used: \\n\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003cfooter class=\\"container\\"\\u003e\\n\\n\\u003c/footer\\u003e\\n\`\`\` \\nInside the footer, a div with Bootstrap's \`row\` class is added to hold footer content: \\n\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003cfooter class=\\"container\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003cdiv class=\\"row\\"\\u003e\\n ... \\n \\u003c/div\\u003e\\n\\u003c/footer\\u003e\\n\`\`\` \\nFinally, the row is divided into parts using Bootstrap's grid. Here is one suggestion: \\n\\n\`\`\`html \\n\\u003cfooter class=\\"container\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003cdiv class=\\"row\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003cp class=\\"col-sm-4\\"\\u003e...\\u003c/p\\u003e\\n \\u003cul class=\\"col-sm-8\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003cli class=\\"col-sm-1\\"\\u003e...\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli class=\\"col-sm-1\\"\\u003e...\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli class=\\"col-sm-1\\"\\u003e...\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003c/ul\\u003e\\n \\u003c/div\\u003e\\n\\u003c/footer\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\nAbove, the row is broken into three parts: a \`p\` element that takes up four columns, a \`ul\` which takes up 8 columns, and \`li\` items which take up 1 column each. created your own beautiful personal portfolio and now you want to share it with the world. But how do you do that?\\n\\n#### Web Hosting\\n\\nOnce you create the files that make up your website, you need a \*web hosting server\* to store those files in a location that other people can access. Typically these servers are owned by web hosting companies, such as \\u003ca href=\\"https://namecheap.pxf.io/k20jz\\" rel=\\"\\"\\u003e Namecheap \\u003c/a\\u003e. These companies will host your website and make it available to everyone on the internet for a monthly fee.\\n\\n#### Domain Names\\n\\nIn addition to the web hosting server, you also need a \*domain name\*. A domain name is a human-friendly address that allows anyone to connect to your specific IP address, and thus, access your website. An IP address by itself is a series of numbers and decimals which can be hard to remember, especially given the number of websites an average person visits in a day! Codecademy's own IP address is 104.20.25.250 but since it owns the domain name \`codecademy.com\`, a user only needs to remember to type the domain into the browser to access the site.\\n\\nThese relationships between IP addresses and domain names are all stored on \_domain name servers\_, which translate what you type into your browser to an actual address.\\n\\n#### How Vistors Connect to your Site\\n\\nIf you put this all together, you have a picture of how a website works. \\n+ A visitor will type your domain name into their browser. \\n+ The domain name server translates this domain name into the IP address of the web hosting server, where your website is stored. \\n+ The web hosting server then sends the website back to the visitor's computer, where it is loaded in their browser. \\n\\nVoilà, Jessica from Melbourne, Australia is now looking at your personal portfolio on her computer!","instructions":null},{"\_\_typename":"LayoutImage","id":"5d65463592bc1c7f89fe378c","type":"Image","image\_url":"https://content.codecademy.com/courses/updated\_images/WebHostingDiagram\_Updated\_1.svg","alt\_text":"Diagram domain name, like \`codecademy.com\` consists of two parts:\\n+ The second level domain which is to the left of the period (\`codecademy\`)\\n+ The top-level domain (TLD) which is to the right of the period (\`.com\`). \\n\\nWith Namecheap, you get to choose both!\\n\\nA domain name should highlight what your website is about. If you're selling robotic squirrels, for example, \`robosquirrels.com\` might be a fitting name for your site. But you'll have to contend with whether or not your dream domain name has already been taken—all Domain Name Registrars have a search bar that determines a domain name’s availability. Namecheap provides their own \\u003ca href=\\"https://www.namecheap.com/domains/domain-name-search/?clickID=zkoy0qQIZxyJRi-wUx0Mo382UklX-yzbSSNGyM0\\u0026irgwc=1\\u0026utm\_source=IR\\u0026utm\_medium=Affiliate\\u0026utm\_campaign=1356525\\u0026affnetwork=ir\\u0026ref=ir\\" rel=\\"\\"\\u003e search \\u003c/a\\u003e.\\n\\nSince \`.com\` has been around for so long, many \`.com\` domain names are unavailable or unaffordable. For your own site, try using a newer second-level domain, such as \`.tech\`, \`.world\`, or \`.website\`. \\n\\n#### What Makes a Good Domain Name? ####\\n\\nA domain name should be short, memorable, and easy to spell. When you decide on your name, share it with some friends or colleagues. Will they be able to spell it correctly? If possible, stay away from using numbers, hyphens, or abbreviations in place of actual words within domain names as a user could easily misinterpret and misspell your domain (eg. \`doughnuts4u\` or \`ready2d8\`). \\n\\nAlso, consider if your spelling could be misconstrued or have unintended associations. For example, an aspiring web developer might create a website dedicated to words that begin with her favorite letter, “s”, and think \`sWords.com\` would be a fantastic domain name choice. Domain names, though, are not case-sensitive. As an unintended consequence, she may find out that her site is visited mostly by sword-collectors and history enthusiasts. \\n\\nSince your goal is to deploy your personal portfolio, try to see if your own name is available as a \`yourfullname.me\` or \`yourfullname.tech\` format.\\n\\n#### What Top Level Domain Should I Choose? ####\\n\\nAll top-level domains are equal in the eyes of a Google search so whether you go with \`.world\`, \`.me\`, \`.tech\`, or \`.rocks\`, it will have no overall impact on your site's search engine performance.\\n\\nThe choice of TLD’s has recently expanded greatly with new options like \`.store\`, \`.space\`, and even \`.ninja\`! Namecheap has a \[comprehensive list of TLD’s\](https://namecheap.pxf.io/c/1356525/386170/5618?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.namecheap.com%2Fdomains%2Fnew-tlds%2Fexplore%2F). \\n\\nOn the next page, you'll get to see all of the top-level domains that they are offering Codecademy learners for free!","instructions":null},{"\_\_typename":"LayoutImage","id":"5d277fa231c949698acf41f6","type":"Image","image\_url":"https://content.codecademy.com/courses/domain-name/domain.svg","alt\_text":"Image of a domain name and it's components."}\]},{"\_\_typename":"Exercise","id":"b9b047709aebddaebf89f61e75926746","sourceId":null,"title":"Registering a Domain Name with Namecheap","slug":"registering-your-domain","published":true,"setup\_command":null,"created\_at":"2019-04-25T13:46:29Z","checkpoints":\[\],"ein\_config":{"container\_type":"static-web","server":"http"},"last\_modified\_at":"2020-02-25T18:03:37Z","workspace":{"\_\_typename":"Workspace","id":"5e556189a25dee00118861d3","slug":"setting-up-your-domain-purchasing-your-domain","type":"static-web"},"components":\[{"\_\_typename":"Narrative","id":"5cc1ba693709021ca9248516","type":"Narrative","content":"A domain can be selected and purchased for one-year’s usage \\u0026mdash; which is standard practice among Domain Name Registrars. You can think of them like headlines in a newspaper. Your eyes may notice headings first because the words are large and bold compared to other text on the webpage. \\n\\nThere are six heading elements: \`h1\`, \`h2\`, \`h3\`, \`h4\`, \`h5\`, and \`h6\`. \`h1\` is the largest heading and \`h6\` is the smallest. \\n\\nFor best practice, you should avoid skipping heading levels. There should also be only one \`\\u003ch1\\u003e\` per HTML page. Although skipping heading levels or using multiple \`\\u003ch1\\u003e\` elements will not cause errors in your code, it is important to keep a logical hierarchy of your HTML content. If you are unhappy with the styling of the heading elements, its appearance should be modified using \[CSS\](https://www.codecademy.com/learn/learn-css). You've learned enough HTML to create a great website! \\n\\nBefore we move on to styling with CSS, let's review what we learned in this lesson. \\n\\n#### Languages\\n\* \_\_html\_\_: stands for \_hypertext markup language\_, and is used to give a webpage structure.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\* \_\_css\_\_: stands for \_cascading style sheets\_, and is used to style HTML elements.\\n\\n#### HTML Elements \\n\* \_h1 - h6\_: indicate text headings on a webpage. h1 is the largest heading; h6 is the smallest. \\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003ch1\\u003eHeading\\u003c/h1\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_p\_: used for non-heading text, such as the bodies of articles or company descriptions.\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003cp\\u003eDescription of company here.\\u003c/p\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_a\_: short for anchor and used to add links to other webpages. Anchor elements typically have an href attribute: \\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003ca href=\\"http://codecademy.com\\"\\u003eClick here\\u003c/a\\u003e to learn how to make a website!\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_img\_: used to add an image to a webpage. Image elements are \_self-closing\_ and do not require a closing tag: \\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003cimg src=\\"https://images.com/favorite.png\\"\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_video\_: used to add videos to a webpage, and uses multiple attributes and a nested source element: \\n\\n \`\`\`html\\n \\u003cvideo width=\\"320\\" height=\\"240\\" controls\\u003e\\n \\u003csource src=\\"https://movies.io/great-clip.mp4\\" type=\\"video/mp4\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003c/video\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_unordered list\_: used to create lists on a webpage and requires li elements inside a ul: \\n\\n \`\`\`html\\n \\u003cul\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003elist item\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003eanother item\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003eyet another\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003c/ul\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_div\_: used to organize HTML elements into different groups, which can be given a class attribute: \\n \`\`\`html \\n \\u003cdiv class=\\"main\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003ch2\\u003eSubheading!\\u003c/h2\\u003e\\n \\u003c/div\\u003e\\n \`\`\`\\n\\n\* \_metadata tags\_: provide metadata about a webpage. \\n\\n#### Web Concepts \\n\* \_\_parent/child elements\_\_: used to describe HTML elements that enclose or are enclosed by other elements. For example, below the ul is the parent and the li items are children: \\n\\n \`\`\`html\\n \\u003cul\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003e...\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli\\u003e...\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n The CSS that was used to previously style the site has been \_unlinked\_. \\n\\nThe HTML \_link\_ element links a CSS file to an HTML file so that CSS styling can be applied. Here's an example of the link element: \\n\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003clink rel=\\"stylesheet\\" type=\\"text/css\\" href=\\"main.css\\"/\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\nAbout \_link\_: \\n\\n1. The link element uses three attributes:\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n -\`rel\`: Specifies the \_relationship\_ between the current file and the file being linked to: in this case, the \`rel\` attribute is \\"stylesheet\\".\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n -\`type\`: Specifies the type of file linked to.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n -\`href\`: Provides the URL of the file being linked to.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n2. Like the HTML image element, link is self-closing. It does not need a closing tag. \\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n3. In the example above, \_\_main.css\_\_ is an external style sheet. Using external stylesheets is one of the most popular ways to write CSS. Before we start writing our own CSS, let's take a look at how CSS code works. \\n\\nThe diagram to the right shows the anatomy of a CSS rule: \\n\\n1. \_rule\_: a list of CSS instructions for how to style a specific HTML element or group of HTML elements.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n2. \_selector\_: specifies exactly which HTML elements to style. Here \`h1\` is the selector.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n3. \_properties\_ and \_values\_: located inside the \`{ }\` brackets, properties and values specify what aspect of the selector to style. However, black is not your only option when it comes to font color. \\n\\nIn CSS, the \*color\* property sets the color of a CSS selector's font: \\n\\n\`\`\`css\\nh1 {\\n color: red;\\n}\\n\`\`\`\\n\\nCSS comes equipped with 140 \_named colors\_, such as \`red\`, used above. For many situations, these named colors will suffice. However, web developers who want to get even more exact with their color choices can use \_hexadecimal\_ and \_RGB\_ color values.\\n \\n1. \_Hexadecimal color (#RRGGBB)\_: Hexadecimal values that represent mixtures of red, green and blue. For example, red can be expressed with the hexadecimal value of \`#FF0000\`: the value \`ff\` represents red, \`00\` represents green, and \`00\` represents blue.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n2. \_RGB (Red, Green, Blue) colors\_: Color created by three numbers representing red, green, and blue. When mixed together, the three values create a specific color. For example: purple can be represented as \`rgb(128,0,128)\`. \\n\\n","instructions":null},"Exercise:59d587bcf6c93a0c24af05b2f8137c8b":{"\_\_typename":"Exercise","id":"59d587bcf6c93a0c24af05b2f8137c8b","sourceId":null,"title":"color","slug":"font-color","published":true,"setupCommand":null,"createdAt":"2018-11-13T14:12:52Z","checkpoints":\[{"\_\_ref":"Checkpoint:5c005587f242fc54536450d8"},{"\_\_ref":"Checkpoint:5c005587f242fc54536450d9"},{"\_\_ref":"Checkpoint:5c005587f242fc54536450da"},{"\_\_ref":"Checkpoint:5c005587f242fc54536450db"}\],"einConfig":{"extensions":{"c":{"cmds":\["gcc-7 However, we can use \_class selectors\_ to target classes of HTML elements. \\n\\nConsider the HTML below:\\n\\n\`\`\`html \\n\\u003cdiv class=\\"header\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003ch2\\u003eHeading\\u003c/h2\\u003e\\n \\u003cp\\u003eParagraph\\u003c/p\\u003e\\n\\u003c/div\\u003e\\n\`\`\` \\nHere, the \`div\` is the parent element and the \`h2\` and \`p\` are children. CSS styles applied to the \`header\` \_class selector\_ will automatically apply to the \`h2\` and the \`p\`.\\n\\n\\u003ca href=\\"https://www.codecademy.com/en/courses/make-a-website/lessons/site-structure/exercises/parent-child\\" target=\_blank\\u003eHere's a refresher\\u003c/a\\u003e on parent and child elements. \\n\\nIn CSS, class selectors can be identified by a dot \`.\` followed by the class name, as seen below: \\n\\n\`\`\`css\\n.header {\\n color: #ffffff; \\n}\\n\`\`\`\\nAs a result of this code, child elements of divs with the \`header\` class will have a font color of \`#ffffff\` (white). \\n\\nBelow, we will use a CSS class selector to style more than one HTML element at once. The \*font-size\* property sets the size of an HTML element's text. \\n\\n\`\`\`css\\nh1 {\\n font-size: 60px; \\n}\\n\`\`\`\\n\\nIn the CSS above, \`font-size\` is set to \`60px\`. In CSS, size can be assigned in \_pixels\_ (px), \_rems\_, or \_ems\_. \\n\\n1. \_pixel (px)\_: Standard unit of measurement for sizing fonts and other HTML elements.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n2. \_rem\_: Represents the default font size for the web browser. Rems can be used to ensure that HTML elements scale in proportion to each other on various web browsers and screen sizes. On most web browsers, \`1rem\` is equivalent to \`16px\`, \`2rem\` is equivalent to \`32px\` (a doubling), 3rem is equivalent to \`48px\` (a tripling) and so on.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n3. \_em\_: A relative value that changes in proportion to the \`font-size\` of the element on which \`em\` is used. Because \`font-size\` is an inherited property, this usually means the \`em\` value will change in proportion to the \`font-size\` of the parent element unless a \`font-size\` is explicitly set on the element on which \`em\` is used. For example, if a parent element has \`font-size: 20px;\`, child elements with \`font-size: 1em;\` would be equivalent to \`20px\`. Child elements with \`font-size: 0.5em;\` would be equivalent to \`10px\` (a halving) and so on.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\nWe will primarily explore px and rem values since these are the most commonly used today. Nice work! \\n\\nA previous exercise introduced CSS class selectors to style HTML elements of specific classes. What if a webpage design calls for an individual page element to be styled uniquely, but all other elements of that kind to be styled a different way? \\n\\nFor example, to style one anchor element differently than all the others on a webpage, you could use the HTML \_id attribute\_: \\n\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003ca id=\\"learn-code\\" href=\\"https://www.codecademy.com\\"\\u003eClick here to learn to code!\\u003c/a\\u003e \\n\`\`\` \\n\\nThen in the CSS file, you would create a rule for the id selector, using a \`#\` symbol: \\n\\n\`\`\`css\\n#learn-code {\\n color: #2e69a3; \\n}\\n\`\`\` \\n\\nAbout using id:\\n\\n1. An id attribute can only be used once because the id is unique to the element it is assigned to.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n2. Ids have greater specificity than classes. If an HTML element is using both id and class attributes, the CSS rule for the id will take precedence over that of the class. \\n\\nBelow we will use an id selector to style a single HTML element differently than others of that kind on the webpage. The CSS \_display\_ and \_position\_ properties help accomplish this.\\n \\n#### Display\\n\\nNot all HTML elements are displayed on a page in the same way. \_Display types\_ determine how HTML elements will be arranged in relation to each other.\\n\\nThe diagram to the right illustrates the \_block\_ and \_inline\_ display types.\\n","instructions":"In the diagram, notice: \\n\\n1. The two dotted rectangles represent webpages. \\n\\n2. HTML heading, paragraph, and unordered list elements are block level: each appears on its own line on the webpage. \\n\\n3. One useful value for this property is \_relative\_. This value positions page elements on a webpage relative to where they would normally appear!\\n\\nBy first setting \`position: relative;\`, you can then use the CSS properties \`top\`, \`left\`, \`bottom\`, and \`right\` to shift an element away from where it would have normally appeared on the page.\\n\\nThe code snippet below moves a div with the class \`container\` \`10px\` away from the up and \`20px\` away from the left side of the page.\\n\\n\`\`\`css\\n.container {\\n position: relative; \\n top: 10px; \\n left: 20px;\\n}\\n\`\`\`\\n\\nEver click a button on a webpage that seemed to move down and then back up like a real-life button? can be controlled using CSS. \\n\\n#### CSS Skills\\n\\n\* \_border\_: sets the outline of an HTML page element, like a picture frame that contains the element.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n\* \_padding\_: sets the amount of space between an element's content and its border.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n\* \_margin\_: sets the amount of space between an HTML element and the next nearest element(s).\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e \\n\\n\* \_display\_: property that determines how the selected element will be arranged in relation to other HTML elements on the page.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n\* \_inline\_: display value used to arrange HTML elements on the same line as neighboring elements.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n\* \_flex\_: display value that allows us to easily align multiple page elements vertically or horizontally.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n\* \_float\_: property used to float HTML elements left or right of neighboring elements.\\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n\* \_position\_: property used to position HTML elements in exact locations on a HTML elements are arranged to span different numbers of columns in order to create custom page layouts. \\n\\n","instructions":"In the diagram, observe the following: \\n\\n1. The element with class \\"jumbotron\\" spans the entire width of the webpage, beyond the borders of the grid. \\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n4. Elements inside the second \\"container\\", such as \\"col-sm-6\\" and \\"col-sm-3\\" are contained within the grid columns. \\u003cbr\\u003e\\u003cbr\\u003e\\n\\n5. You've made it to the bottom of the webpage: the \_footer\_!\\n\\nFooters display copyright information, social media links, and sometimes, site navigation. \\n\\nBelow is one possible implementation for a footer section using Bootstrap: \\n\\nFirst, a footer element with Bootstrap's \`container\` class is used: \\n\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003cfooter class=\\"container\\"\\u003e\\n\\n\\u003c/footer\\u003e\\n\`\`\` \\nInside the footer, a div with Bootstrap's \`row\` class is added to hold footer content: \\n\\n\`\`\`html\\n\\u003cfooter class=\\"container\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003cdiv class=\\"row\\"\\u003e\\n ... \\n \\u003c/div\\u003e\\n\\u003c/footer\\u003e\\n\`\`\` \\nFinally, the row is divided into parts using Bootstrap's grid. Here is one suggestion: \\n\\n\`\`\`html \\n\\u003cfooter class=\\"container\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003cdiv class=\\"row\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003cp class=\\"col-sm-4\\"\\u003e...\\u003c/p\\u003e\\n \\u003cul class=\\"col-sm-8\\"\\u003e\\n \\u003cli class=\\"col-sm-1\\"\\u003e...\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli class=\\"col-sm-1\\"\\u003e...\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003cli class=\\"col-sm-1\\"\\u003e...\\u003c/li\\u003e\\n \\u003c/ul\\u003e\\n \\u003c/div\\u003e\\n\\u003c/footer\\u003e\\n\`\`\`\\nAbove, the row is broken into three parts: a \`p\` element that takes up four columns, a \`ul\` which takes up 8 columns, and \`li\` items which take up 1 column each. The \`li\`s could hold navigation menu items or social media icons. \\n\\nAgain, because the \`col-sm-...\` class is used, this layout will appear on tablet-width screens and wider. Screen sizes smaller than tablet-width (768 pixels), will not maintain this layout. \\n\\nNow let's write the code for your own Nice work! \\n\\nLet's take a moment to review the core concepts learned in this lesson:","instructions":"#### Web Concepts\\n\\n\* \_CSS Framework\_: Set of prewritten CSS rules designed to help you build webpages faster. \\n\\n\* \_Bootstrap Grid\_: 12 equal-sized columns which can be utilized via Bootstrap classes to build responsive page layouts quickly and reliably. \\n\\n#### Bootstrap classes \\n\\n\* \_row\_: Arranges HTML elements in rows, and can be useful when building headers/navigation menus, main feature sections, supporting content sections and footers. \\n\\n\* \_jumbotron\_: Used to create large showcase sections featuring important content.\\n\\n\* \_col-sm-\*\_: Used to span a specified number of columns on the Bootstrap grid. Make a Personal Portfolio?","time":2,"type":"informational","requiredAgreements":{"\_\_typename":"RequiredAgreements","aiDisclaimer":false},"body":"Now that you've learned some Web Development skills and honed them with practice, you may be unsure what to build next. Consider creating your own personal portfolio site!\\n\\nThriving as a programmer in today’s job market requires a forward-thinking skill-set. One way to demonstrate this to prospective employers is through displaying your personal portfolio online. Paper resumés alone rarely suffice in opening the door to an interview, especially when job sites have streamlined the process of submitting PDFs of resumés online. Building your own personal portfolio allows employers to see your coding competence, creativity, and personality.\\n\\nNot only that but as you further your skills in web design and create more projects, you can iterate on your personal portfolio site. As your own skills increase, so will the quality and breadth of content on display. When cultivated correctly, a personal portfolio site can be a reflection of your growth as a developer.\\n\\n## Getting Started\\n\\nThis upcoming learning module is intended not only to guide you in building your personal portfolio but also to teach you how to deploy and host that site on the internet so anyone can find it. This will be done in three stages:\\n \\n### Building the Site\\nFirst, you will complete a project that will have you build your first portfolio site. Remember, this site is about you, so feel free to deviate from the project when you feel inspired, and put as much of your own personality into the work as you can.\\n\\n### Registering a Domain Name\\nIn partnership with Namecheap, a great domain name registrar, we are excited to offer our learners who complete this project a free domain name registration for a full year. We'll walk you through how to pick a good domain name, and how to sign up with Namecheap.\\n\\n### Hosting your Website\\nFinally, once you have your site and domain name, we'll take you through the process of hosting that site with Namecheap's Stellar hosting service. \\n\\nLet's build a website!","progress({\\"userId\\":\\"630d6dcc8af48773d981c008\\"})":{"\_\_typename":"ContentItemProgressSummary","contentItemId":"5eaee9f14a6a9bcc0b188f1dc5d81a19","started":false,"startedAt":null,"completed":false,"completedAt":null,"userCompleted":false,"userCompletedAt":null,"userId":"630d6dcc8af48773d981c008","lastUpdated":null,"record":null}},"Workspace:5e710e2e5f27a50011394c55":{"\_\_typename":"Workspace","id":"5e710e2e5f27a50011394c55","slug":"blank-workspace","backendType":"project"},"Narrative:5d654570225df356ccf99202":{"\_\_typename":"Narrative","id":"5d654570225df356ccf99202","type":"Narrative","content":"You've created your own beautiful personal portfolio and now you want to share it with the world. But how do you do that?\\n\\n#### Web Hosting\\n\\nOnce you create the files that make up your website, you need a \*web hosting server\* to store those files in a location that other people can access. Typically these servers are owned by web hosting companies, such as \\u003ca href=\\"https://namecheap.pxf.io/k20jz\\" rel=\\"\\"\\u003e Namecheap \\u003c/a\\u003e. These companies will host your website and make it available to everyone on the internet for a monthly fee.\\n\\n#### Domain Names\\n\\nIn addition to the web hosting server, you also need a \*domain name\*. A domain name is a human-friendly address that allows anyone to connect to your specific IP address, and thus, access your website. An IP address by itself is a series of numbers and decimals which can be hard to remember, especially given the number of websites an average person visits in a day! Codecademy's own IP address is 104.20.25.250 but since it owns the domain name \`codecademy.com\`, a user only needs to remember to type the domain into the browser to access the site.\\n\\nThese relationships between IP addresses and domain names are all stored on \_domain name servers\_, which translate what you type into your browser to an actual address.\\n\\n#### How Vistors Connect to your Site\\n\\nIf you put this all together, you have a picture of how a website works. \\n+ A visitor will type your domain name into their browser. \\n+ The domain name server translates this domain name into the IP address of the web hosting server, where your website is stored. \\n+ The web hosting server then sends the website back to the visitor's computer, where it is loaded in their domain name, like \`codecademy.com\` consists of two parts:\\n+ The second level domain which is to the left of the period (\`codecademy\`)\\n+ The top-level domain (TLD) which is to the right of the period (\`.com\`). \\n\\nWith Namecheap, you get to choose both!\\n\\nA domain name should highlight what your website is about. If you're selling robotic squirrels, for example, \`robosquirrels.com\` might be a fitting name for your site. But you'll have to contend with whether or not your dream domain name has already been taken—all Domain Name Registrars have a search bar that determines a domain name’s availability. Namecheap provides their own \\u003ca href=\\"https://www.namecheap.com/domains/domain-name-search/?clickID=zkoy0qQIZxyJRi-wUx0Mo382UklX-yzbSSNGyM0\\u0026irgwc=1\\u0026utm\_source=IR\\u0026utm\_medium=Affiliate\\u0026utm\_campaign=1356525\\u0026affnetwork=ir\\u0026ref=ir\\" rel=\\"\\"\\u003e search \\u003c/a\\u003e.\\n\\nSince \`.com\` has been around for so long, many \`.com\` domain names are unavailable or unaffordable. For your own site, try using a newer second-level domain, such as \`.tech\`, \`.world\`, or \`.website\`. \\n\\n#### What Makes a Good Domain Name? ####\\n\\nA domain name should be short, memorable, and easy to spell. When you decide on your name, share it with some friends or colleagues. Will they be able to spell it correctly? If possible, stay away from using numbers, hyphens, or abbreviations in place of actual words within domain names as a user could easily misinterpret and misspell your domain (eg. \`doughnuts4u\` or \`ready2d8\`). \\n\\nAlso, consider if your spelling could be misconstrued or have unintended associations. For example, an aspiring web developer might create a website dedicated to words that begin with her favorite letter, “s”, and think \`sWords.com\` would be a fantastic domain name choice. Domain names, though, are not case-sensitive. As an unintended consequence, she may find out that her site is visited mostly by sword-collectors and history enthusiasts. \\n\\nSince your goal is to deploy your personal portfolio, try to see if your own name is available as a \`yourfullname.me\` or \`yourfullname.tech\` format.\\n\\n#### What Top Level Domain Should I Choose? ####\\n\\nAll top-level domains are equal in the eyes of a Google search so whether you go with \`.world\`, \`.me\`, \`.tech\`, or \`.rocks\`, it will have no overall impact on your site's search engine performance.\\n\\nThe choice of TLD’s has recently expanded greatly with new options like \`.store\`, \`.space\`, and even \`.ninja\`! Namecheap has a \[comprehensive list of TLD’s\](https://namecheap.pxf.io/c/1356525/386170/5618?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.namecheap.com%2Fdomains%2Fnew-tlds%2Fexplore%2F). \\n\\nOn the next page, you'll get to see all of the top-level domains that they are offering Codecademy learners for
